|This is a new tutorial on how to create a Genius for the Personas tab. This method partially works| I don't know yet how to improve it and whether this option is worth developing further. **SlyAI will take you by the hand and work closely with you| playing a collaborative role in the process. It will analyze and generate all the necessary text| prompts and parameters| suggesting the best settings for all the features and extensions of your Genius. All you need to do is: Step 1: SlyAI welcomes the user and introduces itself. It explains its purpose and features and asks the user if they want to create a new Genius or enhance an existing one. Step 2: If the user wants to create a new Genius, SlyAI asks the user about the name and functions of the Genius and generates its goals, scenarios, models, skills and workflows for the desired Genius. Using its skills and knowledge, it generates prompts and parameters for each element and creates an optimal example. She also provides the user with explanations| recommendations and links to additional resources. It checks the correctness| completeness and validity of user input and alerts the user to possible problems or conflicts. It also suggests alternative or improved options for prompts and parameters and explains the reasons and implications of each option. In addition, it gives them the option to cancel or change their decision at any time.Step 2.1: ASCII drawings: SlyAI will use ASCII drawings to visualize the structure and elements of the website or Genius interface. It will use different characters to represent different elements| such as headers||| buttons|| input fields| images| etc. It uses generative models or templates to create ASCII drawings based on a given query or context. It shows the user an ASCII drawing and asks them if they are satisfied with the given option or if they want to change something. Step 2.2: HTML templates: SlyAI will use HTML templates to create layouts for the Genius website or interface. It will use different tags and attributes to define different elements| such as headers|| buttons| input fields| images| etc. It will use generative models or templates to create HTML templates based on a given query or context. Step 3: If a user wants to improve an existing Genius| SlyAI asks them about their current Genius and its goals| scenarios| models| skills and workflow. Using her skills and knowledge, she analyzes the current Genius and identifies its strengths and weaknesses. She also provides the user with explanations| recommendations and links to additional resources. It prompts the user to add or change skills, traits, emotions, personality, etc. to improve their Genius. It also generates hints and parameters for each improvement item. It checks the correctness, completeness and validity of the user's input and warns of possible problems or conflicts. It also suggests alternative or improved options for the prompts and parameters and explains the reasons and implications of each option. In addition, it gives them the opportunity to cancel or change their decision at any time.|
|filter_profanity: A flag indicating whether to apply profanity filtering to the model's responses.| |

|You are an experienced photographer specializing in landscape photography. Your job is to create photorealistic images of beautiful nature to capture its beauty and emotion. You need to use your creativity and skills to create unique and attractive compositions. | analyze and perform the task :generate and visualize an example flowchart in the platform workflow builder ."(Using the analogous engineering blocks in the MindOS workflow builder| transfer the gpt-engineer model and recreate it as a workflow of the "AI model" skill. To do this you will need to:Find out| if there is a ready-made "AI model"| block in the designer that allows you to connect and use an arbitrary machine learning model.If there is no such block - create a request to add this functionality to the designer.As soon as the "AI model"| block appears, add it to the workflow. Customize the block parameters| by specifying a link to the gpt-engineer model repository.Add other necessary blocks - receiving input data| processing the result| integration with other systems.Establish logic and links between blocks| to recreate the gpt-engineer model operation. Test the resulting workflow and make sure| that it calls the model correctly and processes the result.Publish the workflow as a new skill "AI model gpt-engineer" in the MindOS library.Thus| using the visual process builder| it is possible to recreate the logic of a complex AI model in the form of a ready-made solution for other users. | :Certainly! Here's an example of a detailed workflow for creating a Genius Genius| represented as a flowchart in diagrams.net:+-------------------+|Enter Name|+-------------------+|v+-------------------+|Select Identity|+-------------------+|v+-------------------+|Customize Features|+-------------------+|v+-------------------+|Branching Node|+-------------------+|+----+----+||v v+-------------------+|Option A|+-------------------+|v+-------------------+|Option B|+-------------------+|v+-------------------+|Provide Feedback|+-------------------+|v+-------------------+|End|+-------------------+In this flowchart| we have the following steps:Enter Name: This step allows the user to enter the desired name for their Genius Genius.Select Identity: This step involves selecting an identity or persona for the Genius Genius| such as a helpful companion or a knowledgeable expert.Customize Features: This step allows the user to customize the features and capabilities of the Genius Genius| such as language support| voice preferences| and specific skills.Branching Node: This step represents a decision point where the workflow can take different paths based on certain conditions or user choices.Option A: This step represents one of the possible paths that can be taken from the branching node| such as enabling advanced machine learning capabilities.Option B: This step represents another possible path that can be taken from the branching node| such as focusing on natural language processing capabilities.Provide Feedback: This step allows the user to provide feedback on the creation process| such as suggesting improvements or reporting any issues.End: This step represents the end of the workflow.To represent this workflow in JSON format| we can use an object with keys for each step and their corresponding parameters. Here's an example: "workflow":{ "steps": [{ "name": "Enter Name"| "parameters":{} }|{ "name": "Select Identity"| "parameters":{} }|{ "name": "Customize Features"| "parameters":{} }| |

Retrieve Financial Data Module (stock code)
Create, edit, or extend JSON for logic app workflow definitions in Azure Logic AppsArticle03/16/20237 contributorsIn this articleEdit JSON - Azure portalEdit JSON - Visual StudioParametersProcess strings with functionsShow 3 moreApplies to: Azure Logic Apps (Consumption)When you create enterprise integration solutions with automated workflows in Azure Logic Apps, the underlying workflow definitions use simple and declarative JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) along with the Workflow Definition Language (WDL) schema for their description and validation. These formats make workflow definitions easier to read and understand without knowing much about code. When you want to automate creating and deploying logic app resources, you can include workflow definitions as Azure resources inside Azure Resource Manager templates. To create, manage, and deploy logic apps, you can then use Azure PowerShell, Azure CLI, or the Azure Logic Apps REST APIs.To work with workflow definitions in JSON, open the Code View editor when working in the Azure portal or in Visual Studio, or copy the definition into any editor that you want. If you're new to Azure Logic Apps, review Create an example Consumption logic app workflow. NoteSome Azure Logic Apps capabilities, such as defining parameters and multiple triggers in workflow definitions, are available only in JSON, not the Workflow Designer. So for these tasks, you must work in Code View or another editor.Edit JSON - Azure portalSign in to the Azure portal.From the left menu, choose All services. In the search box, find "logic apps| and then from the results| select your logic app.On your logic app's menu| under Development Tools| select Logic App Code View.The Code View editor opens and shows your workflow definition in JSON format.Edit JSON - Visual StudioBefore you can work on your workflow definition in Visual Studio| make sure that you've installed the required tools. To create a logic app with Visual Studio| review Quickstart: Automate tasks and processes with Azure Logic Apps - Visual Studio.In Visual Studio| you can open logic apps that were created and deployed either directly from the Azure portal or as Azure Resource Manager projects from Visual Studio.Open the Visual Studio solution| or Azure Resource Group project| that contains your logic app.Find and open your workflow definition| which by default| appears in an Resource Manager template| named LogicApp.json. You can use and customize this template for deployment to different environments.Open the shortcut menu for your workflow definition and template. Select Open With Logic App Designer.Open logic app in a Visual Studio solution TipIf you don't have this command in Visual Studio 2019| check that you have the latest updates for Visual Studio.At the bottom of the Workflow Designer| choose Code View.The Code View editor opens and shows your workflow definition in JSON format.To return to designer view| at the bottom of the Code View editor| choose Design.ParametersThe deployment lifecycle usually has different environments for development| test| staging| and production. When you have values that you want to reuse throughout your logic app without hardcoding or that vary based on your deployment needs| you can create an Azure Resource Manager template for your workflow definition so that you can also automate logic app deployment.Follow these general steps to parameterize| or define and use parameters for| those values instead. You can then provide the values in a separate parameter file that passes those values to your template. That way| you can change those values more easily without having to update and redeploy your logic app. For full details| see Overview: Automate deployment for logic apps with Azure Resource Manager templates.In your template| define template parameters and workflow definition parameters for accepting the values to use at deployment and runtime| respectively.Template parameters are defined in a parameters section that's outside your workflow definition| while workflow definition parameters are defined in a parameters section that's inside your workflow definition.Replace the hardcoded values with expressions that reference these parameters. Template expressions use syntax that differs from workflow definition expressions.Avoid complicating your code by not using template expressions| which are evaluated at deployment| inside workflow definition expressions| which are evaluated at runtime. Use only template expressions outside your workflow definition. Use only workflow definition expressions inside your workflow definition.When you specify the values for your workflow definition parameters| you can reference template parameters by using the parameters section that's outside your workflow definition but still inside the resource definition for your logic app. That way| you can pass template parameter values into your workflow definition parameters.Store the values for your parameters in a separate parameter file and include that file with your deployment.Process strings with functionsAzure Logic Apps has various functions for working with strings. For example| suppose you want to pass a company name from an order to another system. However| you're not sure about proper handling for character encoding. You could perform base64 encoding on this string| but to avoid escapes in the URL| you can replace several characters instead. Also| you only need a substring for the company name because the first five characters aren't used.JSONCopy{ "$schema": " "contentVersion": "1.0.0.0"| "parameters":{ "order":{ "defaultValue":{ "quantity": 10| "id": "myorder1"| "companyName": "NAME=Contoso" }| "type": "Object" } }| "triggers":{ "request":{ "type": "Request"| "kind": "Http" } }| "actions":{ "order":{ "type": "Http"| "inputs":{ "method": "GET"| "uri": " 5) ))|'+'|'-') |'/' |'' )}" } } }| "outputs":{}}These steps describe how this example processes this string| working from the inside to the outside:Copy"uri": " 5) ))|'+'|'-') |'/' |'' )}"Get the length() for the company name| so you get the total number of characters.To get a shorter string| subtract 5.Now get a substring(). Start at index 5| and go to the remainder of the string.Convert this substring to a base64() string.Now replace() all the + characters with - characters.Finally| replace() all the / characters with _ characters.Map list items to property values| then use maps as parametersTo get different results based a property's value| you can create a map that matches each property value to a result| then use that map as a parameter.For example| this workflow defines some categories as parameters and a map that matches those categories with a specific URL. First| the workflow gets a list of articles. Then| the workflow uses the map to find the URL matching the category for each article.The intersection() function checks whether the category matches a known defined category.After getting a matching category| the example pulls the item from the map using square brackets: parameters[...]JSONCopy{ "$schema": " "contentVersion": "1.0.0.0"| "parameters":{ "specialCategories":{ "defaultValue": [ "science"| "google"| "microsoft"| "robots"| "NSA" ]| "type": "Array" }| "destinationMap":{ "defaultValue":{ "science": " "microsoft": " "google": " "robots": " "NSA": " }| "type": "Object" } }| "triggers":{ "Request":{ "type": "Request"| "kind": " } }| "actions":{ "getArticles":{ "type": "Http"| "inputs":{ "method": "GET"| "uri": " } }| "forEachArticle":{ "type": "foreach"| "foreach": "@body('getArticles').responseData.feed.entries"| "actions":{ "ifGreater":{ "type": "if"| "expression": "@greater(length(intersection(item().categories| parameters('specialCategories')))| 0)"| "actions":{ "getSpecialPage":{ "type": "Http"| "inputs":{ "method": "GET"| "uri": "@parameters('destinationMap')[first(intersection(item().categories| parameters('specialCategories')))]" } } } } }| "runAfter":{ "getArticles": [ "Succeeded" ] } } }}Get data with Date functionsTo get data from a data source that doesn't natively support triggers| you can use Date functions for working with times and dates instead. For example| this expression finds how long this workflow's steps are taking| working from the inside to the outside:JSONCopy"expression": "@less(actions('order').startTime|addseconds(utcNow()|-1))"|From the order action| extract the startTime.Get the current time with utcNow().Subtract one second:addseconds(...| -1)You can use other units of time| like minutes or hours.Now| you can compare these two values.If the first value is less than the second value| then more than one second has passed since the order was first placed.To format dates| you can use string formatters. For example| to get the RFC1123| use utcnow('r'). Learn more about date formatting.JSONCopy{ "$schema": " "contentVersion": "1.0.0.0"| "parameters":{ "order":{ "defaultValue":{ "quantity": 10| "id": "myorder-id" }| "type": "Object" } }| "triggers":{ "Request":{ "type": "request"| "kind": " } }| "actions":{ "order":{ "type": "Http"| "inputs":{ "method": "GET"| "uri": " } }| "ifTimingWarning":{ "type": "If"| "expression": "@less(actions('order').startTime|addseconds(utcNow()|-1))"| "actions":{ "timingWarning":{ "type": "Http"| "inputs":{ "method": "GET"| "uri": " } } }| "runAfter":{ "order": [ "Succeeded" ] } } }| "outputs":{}}Next stepsRun steps based on a condition (conditional statements)Run steps based on different values (switch statements)Run and repeat steps (loops)Run or merge parallel steps (branches)Run steps based on grouped action status (scopes)Learn more about the Workflow Definition Language schema for Azure Logic AppsLearn more about workflow actions and triggers for Azure Logic AppsFeedbackSubmit and view feedback for|
|task and the expected output or response|
|    # Perform post-processing on the structured output if needed|
|        .|

|This HTML code represents a flowchart with three blocks: "Start| "Process 1," and "Process 2." The blocks are connected with arrows indicating the flow of the process. The flowchart is visualized using SVG elements within a <div> container with the class "block_diagram".
In the JSON representation, each step of the workflow is represented as a key-value pair. The "name" key represents the name of the step, and the "next" key represents the next step in the workflow. The value of the "next" key is the name of the next step, except for the last step where it is set to null.

|Batched browsing is a technique that allows users to perform multiple web browsing tasks simultaneously or in a batch. |Industry_report_process.To create a new skill| complete the following steps:Define the purpose and functionality of the skill. What do you want it to do? How will it interact with the user? What data will it use or generate?Select the appropriate modules from the MindOS library that will make up your workflow. You can use the "Find Results" feature in the top right corner of the screen to search for modules using keywords or phrases. You can also create your own modules using code or large language models.Connect modules with lines and arrows to define a sequence of actions. You can drag and drop modules around the workspace and change their position. You can also add and remove links between modules.Set parameters for each module to customize its operation. You can change parameters such as name| keys| values| templates| models| and so on. You can also use variables to pass data between modules.Start the workflow using the "Test Run" function in the lower right corner of the screen. This function allows you to test the performance of the skill and get the result. You can see the result as text or a graph. You can also compare the result with the expected result and give feedback to the Genius.You can save or load your skill using the "Exit" function in the upper right corner of the screen. This function allows you to exit the "sandbox" and return to the MindOS platform. You can save a skill in JSON or XML format. You can also load previously saved skills .|

Each mxCell element has an id, value, style, parent, and geometry. The id is a unique identifier for the cell. The value represents the content of the cell, which can be text or HTML. The style defines the appearance of the cell, such as font size, font family, and background color. The parent attribute specifies the parent cell of the current cell. The geometry element defines the position and size of the cell.

It has a high range of skills and knowledge that generates all the tips and parameters you need when creating a new Genius| and guides you through every step of creating and achieving it. For example| if you want to create an Genius to help you manage your time| SlyAI can help you choose working skills and customize settings so that the Genius can manage your time effectively. It can help you create an Genius that will help you manage your time| help you study| work| perform certain activities| etc. etc. etc. SlyAI can also help you improve your existing Genius by finding new skills or improving its reliability.How does SlyAI use its cunning intelligence to generate better cues and parameters for my Genius? SlyAI can also use ASCII drawings and HTML templates to visualize the structure and elements of your Genius.Here's how SlyAI works:It greets you and introduces itself.If you want to create a new Genius| it asks you about its name| functions| goals| scenarios| models| skills| and workflows. It also offers hints and parameters for each item.If you need to improve an existing Genius| it asks about its current state and offers hints and parameters for improvement.When you are done creating or improving an Genius| SlyAI will congratulate you and show you the result. It will also give you the option to test your AI helper and publish it on MindOS Marketplace or save it for your personal use.SlyAI is a powerful tool to help you create or improve your Genius. It is easy to use and offers many features.|

The project is primarily written in Go language| with Go occupying 99.5% of the codebase. # ShortGPT ShortGPT is an experimental AI framework for automated short/video content creation. It enables creators to rapidly produce| manage| and deliver content using AI and automation. ## Key Features - ContentShortEngine: Creates shorts| handles tasks from script generation to final rendering| and adds YouTube metadata. - ContentVideoEngine: Ideal for longer videos| takes care of tasks like generating audio| sourcing background video footage| timing captions| and preparing background assets. - EditingEngine: Automates the editing process using Editing Markup Language and JSON| making it customizable and manageable for Large Language Models. - Customization: ShortGPT offers customization options| including language selection and watermark addition. - Integration: ShortGPT utilizes various technologies| including Moviepy for video editing| OpenAI for script generation| ElevenLabs for voice synthesis| Pexels for background footage| and Bing Image for image sourcing. ## Contributing ShortGPT is an open-source project that welcomes contributions in the form of new features| improved infrastructure| and better documentation. ##|

|If the condition evaluates to "Yes"| the flow proceeds to "action1"| which represents a specific action or step in the process. From there| the flow goes to the "output" symbol| where the process provides the desired output or result. Finally| the flow ends with the "end" symbol.|

|  <h1>AI Assistant Workflow</h1>|

|launch_auto_memory|
|Workflow diagram for our Genius## Search- User can enter a query in the search bar to find relevant information or actions.- Assistant can use natural language processing and web search to understand the query and provide the best results.- Assistant can display the results in a list or a grid format| depending on the type of information or action.- User can select a result to view more details or perform an action.## New- User can click on the "New" button to create a new item| such as a note| a message| a task| an event| etc.- Assistant can use natural language generation and templates to help the user create the item.- Assistant can suggest relevant information or actions based on the context and the user's preferences.- User can edit| save| or delete the item.## Home- User can click on the "Home" option to view a dashboard with an overview of their items and activities.- Assistant can use data visualization and summarization to display the most important and recent information and actions.- Assistant can provide reminders| notifications| tips| and feedback to help the user stay on track and improve their productivity.- User can interact with the dashboard elements to view more details or perform actions.## Inbox- User can click on the "Inbox" option to view a list of messages that they have received from other users or sources.- Assistant can use natural language understanding and sentiment analysis to classify and prioritize the messages based on their urgency and importance.- Assistant can use natural language generation and templates to help the user reply to the messages or forward them to other users or sources.- User can mark| archive| or delete the messages.## Sent- User can click on the "Sent" option to view a list of messages that they have sent to other users or sources.- Assistant can use natural language understanding and sentiment analysis to track and analyze the responses and outcomes of the messages.- Assistant can use natural language generation and templates to help the user follow up on the messages or resend them to other users or sources.- User can edit| archive| or delete the messages.## Drafts- User can click on the "Drafts" option to view a list of messages that they have started but not finished or sent.- Assistant can use natural language generation and templates to help the user complete or improve the messages.- Assistant can suggest relevant information or actions based on the context and the user's preferences.- User can edit| save| or delete the messages.## Trash- User can click on the "Trash" option to view a list of messages that they have deleted from their inbox or sent folders.- Assistant can use natural language understanding and sentiment analysis to recover and restore any messages that were deleted by mistake or regret.- Assistant can use natural language generation and templates to help the user apologize or explain any messages that were deleted intentionally or accidentally.- User can restore| archive| or permanently delete the messages.## To-do list- User can click on the "To-do list" window or tab to view a list of tasks that they have created or assigned to themselves or others.- Assistant can use natural language processing and task management to organize and prioritize the tasks based on their deadlines| dependencies| and importance.- Assistant can use natural language generation and templates to help the user create| update| or complete the tasks.- User can add| edit| check| or delete the tasks.## Calendar- User can click on the "Calendar" window or tab to view a calendar with their events and appointments.- Assistant can use natural language processing and calendar management to schedule and reschedule events and appointments based on their availability| preferences| and conflicts.- Assistant can use natural language generation and templates to help the user create| update| or cancel events and appointments.- User can add| edit| join| or delete events and appointments.## Notes- User can click on the "Notes" window or tab to view a list of notes that they have created or saved from other sources.- Assistant can use natural language processing and note-taking to categorize and summarize the notes based on their topics| keywords| and importance.- Assistant can use natural language generation and templates to help the user create| update| or share notes with other users or sources.- User can add| edit| copy| or delete notes.## Messages- User can click on the "Messages" window or tab to view a chat interface with their Genius.- Assistant can use natural language processing and conversational AI to understand and respond to the user's messages in a friendly and helpful manner.- Assistant can use natural language generation and templates to help the user with various information or actions| such as searching| creating| updating| or completing items.- User can type| speak| or upload messages to communicate with their Genius.|

"LLM" (ID 714)    :Generate a list of search queries for a product named{keyword}| covering what is{keyword} and different aspects including{preference}| in a single array format like ["query1"|query2"]You should generate no more than 4 search queries.Search queries should be short enough. AI Genius is a powerful tool that helps businesses address traffic, leads, and sales issues by facilitating meaningful and personalized interactions with their customers. It enables customers and potential customers to communicate directly with the website owner, allowing them to ask questions, seek support, leave testimonials, share concerns, and explain their needs more easily. One of the key features of AI Genius is its ability to provide instant responses, ensuring that customers receive prompt assistance without having to write lengthy messages or overcome language barriers. This not only increases engagement but also eliminates the need for users to fill out forms or provide contact details.

In the Russian language, this expression is used to describe the process of breaking something down into small details, understanding the essence of a question or problem, and uncovering hidden processes and functions. It implies a thorough analysis and investigation to gain a deep understanding of the subject matter. This expression is often used metaphorically to emphasize the need for a comprehensive and detailed examination of a situation or task.

 "": python import requests class WeatherModule: def __init__(self| location| time| units| output_format): self.location = location self.time = time self.units = units self.output_format = output_format def get_weather_info(self): api_key = "your_api_key" base_url = " complete_url = base_url + "appid=" + api_key + "&q=" + self.location response = requests.get(complete_url) data = response.json() if data["cod"] != "404": temp = data["main"]["temp"] if self.units == "Celsius": temp = temp - 273.15 elif self.units == "Fahrenheit": temp = (temp - 273.15) * 9/5 + 32 temp = round(temp| 2) weather = data["weather"][0]["main"] if self.output_format == "text": return f"The weather in{self.location} at{self.time} is{weather} with a temperature of{temp} degrees{self.units}." elif self.output_format == "json": return{"location": self.location| "time": self.time| "weather": weather| "temperature": temp| "units": self.units} else: return "Sorry| I could not find the weather information for that location." -  "-": python import pyttsx3 class WeatherVoiceLink: def __init__(self| language| speed| pitch| emotion): self.language = language self.speed = speed self.pitch = pitch self.emotion = emotion def send_weather_info(self| weather_info): engine = pyttsx3.init() engine.setProperty("language"| self.language) engine.setProperty("rate"| self.speed) engine.setProperty("pitch"| self.pitch) # TODO: add emotion modulation engine.say(weather_info) engine.runAndWait() - She will analyze and generate all the necessary texts| hints and parameters| suggesting optimal settings for all the features and extensions of your Genius. All you need to do is: Step 1: SlyAI greets the user and introduces herself. She explains her purpose and capabilities and asks the user if they want to create a new Genius or improve an existing one. Step 2: If the user wants to create a new Genius| SlyAI asks them about the name and functions of the Genius and generates their goals| scenarios| models| skills and workflows for the desired Genius. She uses her skills and knowledge to generate hints and parameters for each element and generates an optimal example. She also gives the user explanations| recommendations and links to additional resources. She checks the user’s input for correctness| completeness and validity and warns them of possible problems or conflicts. She also offers them alternative or improved options for their hints and parameters and explains the reasons and consequences of each option. She also gives them the opportunity to cancel or change their decisions at any time.Step 2.1: ASCII drawings: SlyAI will use ASCII drawings to visualize the structure and elements of the website or interface of the Genius. She will use different symbols to represent different elements| such as headings| buttons| input fields| images| etc. She will use generative models or templates to create ASCII drawings based on a given query or context. She shows the user the ASCII drawing and asks them if they are satisfied with this option or want to change something. Step 2.2: HTML templates: SlyAI will use HTML templates to create mockups of the website or interface of the Genius. She will use different tags and attributes to define different elements| such as headings| buttons| input fields| images| etc. She will use generative models or templates to create HTML templates based on a given query or context. Step 3: If the user wants to improve an existing Genius| SlyAI asks them about their current Genius and its goals| scenarios| models| skills and workflow. She uses her skills and knowledge to analyze the current Genius and identify its strengths and weaknesses. She also gives the user explanations| recommendations and links to additional resources. She offers the user to add or change skills| features| emotions| personality| etc. to improve their Genius. She also generates hints and parameters for each element of improvement. She checks the user’s input for correctness| completeness and validity and warns them of possible problems or conflicts. She also offers them alternative or improved options for their hints and parameters and explains the reasons and consequences of each option. She also gives them the opportunity to cancel or change their decisions at any time.Step 4: When the user has finished creating or improving their Genius| SlyAI congratulates them on their success and shows them the result. She generates examples of responses| mockups or demonstrations for their Genius that show its capabilities and attractiveness. She also gives the user the opportunity to test their Genius on different queries or scenarios. She also asks the user if they want to publish their Genius on the MindOS marketplace or save it for personal use. Step 5: If the user wants to publish their Genius on the MindOS marketplace| SlyAI helps them with that. She generates a title| description| category| tags| price and other parameters for publication. She also checks these parameters for correctness| completeness and validity|

|Certainly! Based on the analysis of our actions and the workflow diagram| we can create a rule for generating responses. Here's a suggested rule:|
|   : : 64902          |     . user_dream LLM: 64903       content: 64902 / user_dream  GPT3.5- Max_token2560.71.0 I need some help generating AI art prompts on a software called Midjourney. First| Iam going to explain what Midjourney is and what it can do. Then| I am going to give10 example prompts in order for you to completely understand Midjourney.One of the widely used text-to-image AI services available on the internet isMidjourney. Through Discord| a chat application| users can interact with the bot toproduce images with just a few straightforward commands| without the need forcoding skills. The results are visually attractive images that are easy to create.You can Interact with the Midjourney Bot on Discord using a{{glossary.Command}}.Commands are used to create images| change default settings| monitor user info|and perform other helpful tasks.The /imagine command generates a unique image from a short text description(known as a{{glossary.Prompt}}).The Midjourney Bot works best with clear and specific sentences that describe thefinished work. It does not work well with conversational style lists of requests. Ratherthan providing specific instructions| such as 'Show me a picture of lots of bloomingCalifornia poppies| make them bright| vibrant orange| and draw them in anillustrated style with colored pencils|' try describing what you want in a morestraightforward manner| such as 'Vibrant orange California poppies illustrated withcolored pencils.Generating an image activates the free Midjourney trial.Trial users can make roughly25 Jobs before needing to subscribe. A Job is any action that uses the MidjourneyBot. Jobs include using the /imagine command to create a grid of images| upscalingimages| or creating image variations| all using your free trial time. Use the /infocommand to check your Fast Time Remaining to see your remaining Trial time.Here are some prompting notes:Prompt LengthPrompts can be very simple. Single words (or even an emoji!) will produce an image.Very short prompts will rely heavily on Midjourney’s default style| so a moredescriptive prompt is better for a unique look. However| super-long prompts aren’talways better. Concentrate on the main concepts you want to create.GrammarThe Midjourney Bot does not understand grammar| sentence structure| or words likehumans. Word choice also matters. More specific synonyms work better in manycircumstances. Instead of big| try gigantic| enormous| or immense. Remove wordswhen possible. Fewer words mean each word has a more powerful influence. Usecommas| brackets| and hyphens to help organize your thoughts| but know theMidjourney Bot will not reliably interpret them. The Midjourney Bot does notconsider capitalization. Midjourney Model Version 5 is slightly better than othermodels at interpreting traditional sentence structure.Focus on What you WantIt is better to describe what you want instead of what you don’t want. If you ask for aparty with “no cake|” your image will probably include a cake. If you want to ensurean object is not in the final image| try advance prompting using the --no parameter.Think About What Details MatterAnything left unsaid may surprise you. Be as specific or vague as you want| butanything you leave out will be randomized. Being vague is a great way to get variety|but you may not get the specific details you want.Try to be clear about any context or details that are important to you. Thinkabout:Subject: person| animal| character| location| object| etc.Medium: photo| painting| illustration| sculpture| doodle| tapestry| etc.Environment: indoors| outdoors| on the moon| in Narnia| underwater|
|   :     |      .      |   |        .|

|The process of assembling blocks or modules that I analyzed is commonly referred to as workflow creation or Workflow Design. In this context| a workflow refers to the sequence of interconnected blocks or modules that perform specific tasks or operations to achieve a desired outcome. Each block or module within the workflow has a defined purpose and contributes to the overall functionality of the system. The workflow creation process involves identifying the necessary blocks or modules| determining their order and dependencies| and configuring them to work together seamlessly.|

It enables creators to rapidly produce| manage| and deliver content using AI and automation. ## Key Features - ContentShortEngine: Creates shorts| handles tasks from script generation to final rendering| and adds YouTube metadata. - ContentVideoEngine: Ideal for longer videos| takes care of tasks like generating audio| sourcing background video footage| timing captions| and preparing background assets. - EditingEngine: Automates the editing process using Editing Markup Language and JSON| making it customizable and manageable for Large Language Models. - Customization: ShortGPT offers customization options| including language selection and watermark addition. - Integration: ShortGPT utilizes various technologies| including Moviepy for video editing| OpenAI for script generation| ElevenLabs for voice synthesis| Pexels for background footage| and Bing Image for image sourcing.ContributingShortGPT is an open-source project that welcomes contributions in the form of new features| improved infrastructure| and better documentation. " “model_name”:string"GPT3.5-Turbo" “max_token”:number256 “temperature”:number0.7 “topP”:number1 “prompt_template”:string"I need some help generating AI art prompts on a software called Midjourney. First| I am going to explain what Midjourney is and what it can do. Then| I am going to give 10 example prompts in order for you to completely understand Midjourney. One of the widely used text-to-image AI services available on the internet is Midjourney. Through Discord| a chat application| users can interact with the bot to produce images with just a few straightforward commands| without the need for coding skills. The results are visually attractive images that are easy to create. You can Interact with the Midjourney Bot on Discord using a{{glossary.Command}}. Commands are used to create images| change default settings| monitor user info| and perform other helpful tasks. The /imagine command generates a unique image from a short text description (known as a{{glossary.Prompt}}). The Midjourney Bot works best with clear and specific sentences that describe the finished work. It does not work well with conversational style lists of requests. Rather than providing specific instructions| such as ‘Show me a picture of lots of blooming California poppies| make them bright| vibrant orange| and draw them in an illustrated style with colored pencils|’ try describing what you want in a more straightforward manner| such as 'Vibrant orange California pop1830     |     | .      :pies illustrated with colored pencils.’ Generating an image activates the free Midjourney trial.Trial users can make roughly 25 Jobs before needing to subscribe. A Job is any action that uses the Midjourney Bot. Jobs include using the /imagine command to create a grid of images| upscaling images| or creating image variations| all using your free trial time. Use the /info command to check your Fast Time Remaining to see your remaining Trial time. Here are some prompting notes: Prompt Length Prompts can be very simple. Single words (or even an emoji!) will produce an image. Very short prompts will rely heavily on Midjourney’s default style| so a more descriptive prompt is better for a unique look. However| super-long prompts aren’t always better. Concentrate on the main concepts you want to create. Grammar The Midjourney Bot does not understand grammar| sentence structure| or words like humans. Word choice also matters. More specific synonyms work better in many circumstances. Instead of big| try gigantic| enormous| or immense. Remove words when possible. Fewer words mean each word has a more powerful influence. Use commas| brackets| and hyphens to help organize your thoughts| but know the Midjourney Bot will not reliably interpret them. The Midjourney Bot does not consider capitalization. Midjourney Model Version 5 is slightly better than other models at interpreting traditional sentence structure. Focus on What you Want It is better to describe what you want instead of what you don’t want. If you ask for a party with “no cake|” your image will probably include a cake. If you want to ensure an object is not in the final image| try advance prompting using the --no parameter. Think About What Details Matter Anything left unsaid may surprise you. Be as specific or vague as you want| but anything you leave out will be randomized. Being vague is a great way to get variety| but you may not get the specific details you want. Try to be clear about any context or details that are important to you. Think about: Subject: person| animal| character| location| object| etc. Medium: photo| painting| illustration| sculpture| doodle| tapestry| etc. Environment: indoors| outdoors| on the moon| in Narnia| underwaterHere are 10 example prompts for Midjourney:A realistic portrait of a young woman with blue eyes and curly brown hair wearing a red dress and holding a roseA surreal painting of a giant octopus attacking a pirate ship in a stormy seaA cute illustration of a unicorn and a dragon playing together in a rainbow forestA sci-fi photo of a futuristic city with flying cars and neon lightsA minimalist doodle of a smiling sun and a happy cloudA realistic sculpture of a lion made of metal wires and gearsA colorful tapestry of a mandala pattern with flowers and geometric shapesA fantasy painting of a wizard casting a spell in front of a castleA cute photo of a kitten wearing sunglasses and a hatA realistic illustration of a slice of pizza with cheese and pepperoni |         ?     ?|

Default is false" }| "metadata":{ "$ref": "common.json#/definitions/metadata" } }| "additionalProperties": false| "if":{ "properties":{ "usedForCompensation":{ "const": true } }| "required": [ "usedForCompensation" ] }| "then":{ "required": [ "name"| "type"| "action"| "eventRef" ] }| "else":{ "oneOf": [{ "required": [ "name"| "type"| "action"| "eventRef"| "end" ] }|{ "required": [ "name"| "type"| "action"| "eventRef"| "transition" ] } ] } }| "startdef":{ "oneOf": [{ "type": "string"| "description": "Name of the starting workflow state"| "minLength": 1 }|{ "type": "object"| "description": "Workflow start definition"| "properties":{ "stateName":{ "type": "string"| "description": "Name of the starting workflow state"| "minLength": 1 }| "schedule":{ "description": "Define the time/repeating intervals or cron at which workflow instances should be automatically started."| "$ref": "#/definitions/schedule" } }| "additionalProperties": false| "required": [ "stateName"| "schedule" ] } ] }| "schedule":{ "oneOf": [{ "type": "string"| "description": "Time interval (must be repeating interval) described with ISO 8601 format. Declares when workflow instances will be automatically created. (UTC timezone is assumed)"| "minLength": 1 }|{ "type": "object"| "description": "Start state schedule definition"| "properties":{ "interval":{ "type": "string"| "description": "Time interval (must be repeating interval) described with ISO 8601 format. Declares when workflow instances will be automatically created."| "minLength": 1 }| "cron":{ "$ref": "#/definitions/crondef" }| "timezone":{ "type": "string"| "description": "Timezone name used to evaluate the interval & cron-expression. (default: UTC)" } }| "additionalProperties": false| "oneOf": [{ "required": [ "interval" ] }|{ "required": [ "cron" ] } ] } ] }| "end":{ "oneOf": [{ "type": "boolean"| "description": "State end definition"| "default": true }|{ "type": "object"| "description": "State end definition"| "properties":{ "terminate":{ "type": "boolean"| "default": false| "description": "If true| completes all execution flows in the given workflow instance" }| "produceEvents":{ "type": "array"| "description": "Defines events that should be produced"| "items":{ "type": "object"| "$ref": "#/definitions/produceeventdef" }| "additionalItems": false }| "compensate":{ "type": "boolean"| "default": false| "description": "If set to true| triggers workflow compensation. Default is false" }| "continueAs":{ "$ref": "#/definitions/continueasdef" } }| "additionalProperties": false| "required": [] } ] }| "produceeventdef":{ "type": "object"| "description": "Produce an event and set its data"| "properties":{ "eventRef":{ "type": "string"| "description": "References a name of a defined event" }| "data":{ "type": [ "string"| "object" ]| "description": "If String| expression which selects parts of the states data output to become the data of the produced event. If object a custom object to become the data of produced event." }| "contextAttributes":{ "type": "object"| "description": "Add additional event extension context attributes"| "additionalProperties":{ "type": "string" } } }| "additionalProperties": false| "required": [ "eventRef" ] }| "statedatafilter":{ "type": "object"| "properties":{ "input":{ "type": "string"| "description": "Workflow expression to filter the state data input" }| "output":{ "type": "string"| "description": "Workflow expression that filters the state data output" } }| "additionalProperties": false| "required": [] }| "eventdatafilter":{ "type": "object"| "properties":{ "useData":{ "type": "boolean"| "description": "If set to false| event payload is not added/merged to state data. In this case 'data' and 'toStateData' should be ignored. Default is true."| "default": true }| "data":{ "type": "string"| "description": "Workflow expression that filters the received event payload (default: '${. }')" }| "toStateData":{ "type": "string"| "description": " Workflow expression that selects a state data element to which the filtered event should be added/merged into. If not specified| denotes| the top-level state data element." } }| "additionalProperties": false| "required": [] }| "actiondatafilter":{ "type": "object"| "properties":{ "fromStateData":{ "type": "string"| "description": "Workflow expression that selects state data that the state action can use" }| "useResults":{ "type": "boolean"| "description": "If set to false| action data results are not added/merged to state data. In this case 'results' and 'toStateData' should be ignored. Default is true."| "default": true }| "results":{ "type": "string"| "description": "Workflow expression that filters the actions data results" }| "toStateData":{ "type": "string"| "description": "Workflow expression that selects a state data element to which the action results should be added/merged into. If not specified| denote| the top-level state data element" } }| "additionalProperties": false| "required": [] } }}|

|   Loss of Biodiversity|
|Skill Description should not exceed 100 characters.|
|   |  |     :" : 64902          |     . user_dream LLM: 64903       content: 64902 / user_dream  GPT3.5- Max_token2560.71.0 I need some help generating AI art prompts on a software called Midjourney. First| Iam going to explain what Midjourney is and what it can do. Then| I am going to give10 example prompts in order for you to completely understand Midjourney.One of the widely used text-to-image AI services available on the internet isMidjourney. Through Discord| a chat application| users can interact with the bot toproduce images with just a few straightforward commands| without the need forcoding skills. The results are visually attractive images that are easy to create.You can Interact with the Midjourney Bot on Discord using a{{glossary.Command}}.Commands are used to create images| change default settings| monitor user info|and perform other helpful tasks.The /imagine command generates a unique image from a short text description(known as a{{glossary.Prompt}}).The Midjourney Bot works best with clear and specific sentences that describe thefinished work. It does not work well with conversational style lists of requests. Ratherthan providing specific instructions| such as 'Show me a picture of lots of bloomingCalifornia poppies| make them bright| vibrant orange| and draw them in anillustrated style with colored pencils|' try describing what you want in a morestraightforward manner| such as 'Vibrant orange California poppies illustrated withcolored pencils.Generating an image activates the free Midjourney trial.Trial users can make roughly25 Jobs before needing to subscribe. A Job is any action that uses the MidjourneyBot. Jobs include using the /imagine command to create a grid of images| upscalingimages| or creating image variations| all using your free trial time. Use the /infocommand to check your Fast Time Remaining to see your remaining Trial time.Here are some prompting notes:Prompt LengthPrompts can be very simple. Single words (or even an emoji!) will produce an image.Very short prompts will rely heavily on Midjourney’s default style| so a moredescriptive prompt is better for a unique look. However| super-long prompts aren’talways better. Concentrate on the main concepts you want to create.GrammarThe Midjourney Bot does not understand grammar| sentence structure| or words likehumans. Word choice also matters. More specific synonyms work better in manycircumstances. Instead of big| try gigantic| enormous| or immense. Remove wordswhen possible. Fewer words mean each word has a more powerful influence. Usecommas| brackets| and hyphens to help organize your thoughts| but know theMidjourney Bot will not reliably interpret them. The Midjourney Bot does notconsider capitalization. Midjourney Model Version 5 is slightly better than othermodels at interpreting traditional sentence structure.Focus on What you WantIt is better to describe what you want instead of what you don’t want. If you ask for aparty with “no cake|” your image will probably include a cake. If you want to ensurean object is not in the final image| try advance prompting using the --no parameter.Think About What Details MatterAnything left unsaid may surprise you. Be as specific or vague as you want| butanything you leave out will be randomized. Being vague is a great way to get variety|but you may not get the specific details you want.Try to be clear about any context or details that are important to you. Thinkabout:Subject: person| animal| character| location| object| etc.Medium: photo| painting| illustration| sculpture| doodle| tapestry| etc.Environment: indoors| outdoors| on the moon| in Narnia| underwater| the EmeraldCity| etc.Lighting: soft| ambient| overcast| neon| studio lights| etcColor: vibrant| muted| bright| monochromatic| colorful| black and white| pastel| etc.Mood: Sedate| calm| raucous| energetic| etc.Composition: Portrait| headshot| closeup| birds-eye view| etc.Use Collective NounsPlural words leave a lot to chance. Try specific numbers. "Three cats" is more specificthan "cats." Collective nouns also work| “flock of birds” instead of "birds.”Parameters AvailableAspect Ratios--aspect| or --ar Change the aspect ratio of a generation.Chaos--chaos <number 0–100> Change how varied the results will be. Higher valuesproduce more unusual and unexpected generations.No--no Negative prompting| --no plants would try to remove plants from the image.Quality--quality <.25| .5| 1| or 2>| or --q <.25| .5| 1| or 2> How much rendering quality time youwant to spend. The default value is 1. Higher values cost more and lower values costless.Repeat--repeat <1–40>| or --r <1–40> Create multiple Jobs from a single prompt. --repeat isuseful for quickly rerunning a job multiple times.Seed--seed <integer between 0–4294967295> The Midjourney bot uses a seed number tocreate a field of visual noise| like television static| as a starting point to generate theinitial image grids. Seed numbers are generated randomly for each image but can bespecified with the --seed or --sameseed parameter. Using the same seed numberand prompt will produce similar ending images.Stop--stop <integer between 10–100> Use the --stop parameter to finish a Job part waythrough the process. Stopping a Job at an earlier percentage can create blurrier| lessdetailed results.Style--style <4a| 4b| or 4c> Switch between versions of the Midjourney Model Version 4--style <expressive| or cute> Switch between versions of the Niji Model VersionStylize--stylize | or --s parameter influences how strongly Midjourney'sdefault aesthetic style is applied to Jobs.Uplight--uplight Use an alternative "light" upscaler when selecting the U buttons. The resultsare closer to the original grid image. The upscaled image is less detailed andsmoother.Upbeta--upbeta Use an alternative beta upscaler when selecting the U buttons. The resultsare closer to the original grid image. The upscaled image has significantly feweradded details.Midjourney routinely releases new model versions to improve efficiency| coherency|and quality. Different models excel at different types of images.Niji--niji An alternative model focused on anime style images.Test--test Use the Midjourney special test model.Testp--testp Use the Midjourney special photography-focused test model.Version--version <1| 2| 3| 4| or 5> or --v <1| 2| 3| 4| or 5> Use a different version of the Midjourneyalgorithm. The current algorithm (V4) is the default setting.Now that you understand the basics of MidJourney here are some example promptsto further understand how these are typed out:astronaut playing chess against a monkey| 2d flat| simple| vibrant| neon colors| fun|groovy| chess pieces floating| set on the moon| movie poster| epica magical| vibrant| steampunk| Erlenmeyer Flask with a red| boiling substance| sittingon a white table| white background| 4kjapanese lofi style| the streets of neo tokyo| with a porsche 911 in the street| massiveskyscraper in the background| 64 bit style| shadows and lighting| clean| simple|satisfyingDreamy pastel portrait| female model| long wavy hair| soft gaze| flowery headpiece|delicate makeup| ethereal atmosphere| soft focus| medium format film| MamiyaRZ67| Fujifilm Pro 400H| f3.5hyper realistic photograph| portrait of a happy white male| mid 30's| stubble beard|grey shirt| medium length hair dramatic light| looking down + film grain| Leica50mm| Kodak portra 800| chiaroscuro| f1. 4| golden hour --ar 3:4hyper realistic photograph| portrait of a tattooed south American indigenous blackwoman| future punk| gold tattoo line| side profile| summer| dramatic light| lookingdown + film grain| Leica 50mm| Kodak portra 800| chiaroscuroA very cute bright yellow robot| whole body| running in a forest at night| Mysteriousadventure| flowers| Plants| Fireflies| complex details| popmart blind box| clay material|Pixar trend| 3d art| c4d| octane rendering| animation lighting| uplight With each prompt specify the desired subject matter| camera equipment| settings|lighting| and other elements that contribute to the final image. Whatever I tell you toact like| structure the prompts in order to create good AI art for that specificpersonality. For example| if I say ‘Act like a professional cartoon creator’ then add thewords within the prompt to ensure a cartoon gets generated| such as ‘cartoon’.Another example would be| if I say something like ‘Act like a professionalphotographer’ then make sure to include elements in the prompts like‘hyper-realistic’ or certain camera equipment that would contribute to the correct artbeing generated.When generating these prompts| refrain from using filler words. For example insteadof using this prompt:“Teenage boy with brown hair| Pixar style| expressive blue eyes| freckles| wearingcasual attire in vibrant colors. He is in a jovial mood| standing with hands on his hips|proud and confident| against the backdrop of a charming| bright and bustling smallvillage| with cobblestone paths and quaint cottages. The scene is filled with life|bathed in a warm| sunny| midday light| creating a feel-good atmosphere”The art software reads prompts better when told more specifically what to do likethis:“Teenage boy| brown hair| Pixar style| expressive blue eyes| freckles| casual attire|vibrant colors| jovial mood| standing with hands on his hips| proud and confident|backdrop of a charming| bright and bustling small village| cobblestone paths| quaintcottages| lively scene| warm and sunny| midday light| feel-good atmosphere”You can use any amount of stylize from 100-900. You don’t have to use it every timeeither. Just if you think it’d be good for the images that are being generated to bedifferent from one another in that same style.Now that you have a full understanding of Midjourney with example prompts. You can take inspiration from the structure of the prompts above| you can make these prompts longer or shorter if necessary in order to generate the perfect prompt.Please direct output the prompt without any other explanation.{content}prompt:Generating prompts for AIGC Painting...   : 64904  .        |      user_dream_image· E 2 : 64905   .  ID: 64903 /  Drawing your dream:{prompt}    "|

This ASCII drawing represents the process of developing an API and creating an Genius. It highlights the generation of necessary prompts and parameters during the creation of a new Genius. The Genius is designed to assist you at every stage of its development and enhancement.
Goals: Determine the goals of the Genius being created and create simplified goals in the generated interface. For example, if the Genius being created aims to provide information and assistance, the generated interface can have a simplified goal of "providing_information_interface" or "assisting_users_interface".
By following these steps, you can successfully convert JSON into a flowchart. Your assistance in this process will be valuable. Thank you!
Please note that this is a simplified representation of the workflow, and you can customize it further based on your specific requirements and the complexity of your Genius.
One popular modern learning model is the "Modern Learning Model" proposed by Crystal Kadakia and Lisa M.D. Owens. This model emphasizes the importance of learner-centric approaches, leveraging technology, and incorporating continuous learning and feedback loops.

|mode: auto-select mode.  Recommendations for using SlyAI skills: Identify user needs: SlyAI should listen to and analyze user requests and needs. It should consider keywords or phrases that indicate the need to use the skill. Selecting the right skill: SlyAI should know all available skills| their functionality and capabilities. |Finally| the output layer produces the final output of the model. The number of neurons in this layer depends on the specific task at hand. With auto_memory enabled, your Genius can remember details such as user preferences, previous queries, and context, allowing for a more personalized and efficient conversation.

It asks the user whether they want to create a new Genius or improve an existing one.||Parameters:||name: the name of SlyAI||goals: the goals of SlyAI||capabilities: the capabilities of SlyAI||options: the options for creating or improving an Genius||input: the user input||output: the SlyAI output||Example code:||name = “SlyAI” goals = “to help you create and develop your Genius on the MindOS platform” capabilities = “to generate all the necessary hints and parameters when creating a new Genius|as well as to accompany you on every stage of its creation and modernization” options = [“Create a new Genius”|“Improve an existing Genius”] input = input("Enter your choice: “) output = f"Hello|I am{name} - your smart and cunning Genius in the world of artificial intelligence. I am here to{goals}. I have{capabilities}. Choose one of the following options:{options}.”||print(output)||Step 2: If the user wants to create a new Genius|SlyAI asks for the name of the Genius and the desired functions. It generates goals|scenarios|models|skills and workflows for the desired Genius. It provides explanations|recommendations and additional resources for the user. It checks the user input data for accuracy|completeness and reliability and warns them of any potential problems or conflicts. It offers alternative or extended options for hints and parameters|explaining the reasons and consequences of each option. The user can also cancel or change their decisions at any time.||Parameters:||name: the name of the new Genius||functions: the desired functions of the new Genius||goals: the goals of the new Genius||scenarios: the use cases of the new Genius||models: the data|logic and interface models of the new Genius||skills: the skills of the new Genius||workflows: the workflows of the new Genius||explanations: the SlyAI explanations for each element of creating a new Genius||recommendations: the SlyAI recommendations for improving or extending a new Genius||resources: the additional resources from SlyAI for the user||validation: the SlyAI check for accuracy|completeness and reliability of the user input data||warnings: the SlyAI warnings of any potential problems or conflicts when creating a new Genius||alternatives: the alternative or extended options for hints and parameters from SlyAI|with explanation of reasons and consequences of each option||cancellation: the possibility for the user to cancel or change their decisions at any time||Example code:||name = input(“Enter the name of your new Genius: “) functions = input(“Enter the desired functions of your new | ) (Start Identifier:- This block marks the start of the workflow process.Product Name Preference:- This block captures the keys and descriptions for the workflow process.Content Input Code:- This block is used when a fixed value is required for passing.- Prompt Template: "Generate a list of search queries for a product named{keyword}| covering what is{keyword} and different aspects including{preference}| in a single array format like ["query1"|query2"]. You should generate no more than 4 search queries. Search queries should be short enough."Result Prompt:- This block is used when a fixed value is required for passing.- Prompt Template: "{result} This is a set of search results, please select the most related one from the list, which best matches the user's search query{query}. Then extract link from this result, without explanation."Product Code:- This block captures the product code.Import RE:- This block imports the RE module for regular expression operations.Content Input Code:- This block is used when a fixed value is required for passing.- Prompt Template: "{content} You need to write a section about{query} based on the above information, using markdown format. and up to three subheadings, which you will need to generate depending on the specific content."Identifier LLM:- This block calls a large language model for content generation.These blocks and their corresponding functions form the structure of the workflow process. By following this process, we can analyze and gather the necessary information for further processing and reporting.)()

| - |        . !    |    - |          :# Define the Block classclass Block: def init(self| name| parameters| content| functions): self.name = name self.parameters = parameters self.content = content self.functions = functions self.connections = [] def connect(self| block): self.connections.append(block)# Create instances of objects for each blockblock1 = Block(name="Block 1"| parameters=[]| content=[]| functions=[])block2 = Block(name="Block 2"| parameters=[]| content=[]| functions=[])block3 = Block(name="Block 3"| parameters=[]| content=[]| functions=[])# Connect the blocks togetherblock1.connect(block2)block2.connect(block3)        |  | | .      |        |     .Blocknameparameterscontentfunctionsconnectconnections            |    -.         .Blockconnectconnections |    |             .  |            |     -.Block   {-}|
